description:
Come fly with Rooby Roo as you learn your ABCs. Rooby's banners show each letter in both uppercase and lowercase, and the order they follow in the alphabet.

In Rooby’s ABC, players take turns drawing one of the 26 letter tokens from the bag, they then place them on one of the five public alphabet boards with the matching letter (each board contains 4 to 6 unique letters of the alphabet). When a player completes a board, they collect a Rooby token, and the player with the most Rooby tokens when all the letters have been played wins the game.

—description from the publisher

You look at the wrecked Huey, thankful you survived the crash. It got hit somewhere over the jungle. You lost the pilot. The gunner just fell out. Gone. On your way down you saw a glimpse of the other Huey. You think it got hit too, but you can't be sure. You look around at your squad — wild-eyed Marines fresh out of boot camp — and sigh heavily. You gotta move fast. VC will be coming...

Purple Haze is an immersive story-creation Tactical level Campaign wargame for 1 to 4 players that drops you into the heart of darkness: Vietnam, 1967. You lead a squad of U.S. Marines through the dense jungles, flooded rice paddies, and straw-thatched villages of a war-torn country. Gut-wrenching choices will determine the fate of you and your mission, showing if you have what it takes to survive.

It is in part a story-creation game, in part a Tactical level wargame, and in part a Campaign game. Your decisions determine the story. Your tactics decide the outcome of life and death firefights. Your men will suffer. Some won't make it home. Those that do will get wiser, get tougher. The goal: Complete the mission, and get out alive.

Bag of Ice is an abstract push-your-luck game, played with Looney pyramids, where players compete to be the first one to reach 60 points.

On their turn, players draw pyramids from a bag until they bust by drawing a red pyramid, or voluntarily stop drawing. If they stop, they receive points based on the stacks of pyramids they can assemble and the sizes of the remaining pyramids.

Green Deal is a strategic cannabis themed card game, for 2-6 players, where your strategy gets busted anyways. This action-packed game takes you directly into another Universe.

Build your Green Business by collecting pairs and gain points with every Deal. But be careful, you’ve to watch out for Donut-Cops, Aliens, Thieves. Protect yourself with the help of Skunks, playing Hide or with the good old corrupted Donut-Cop. You think you are winning the Game? Within the Green Universe you should never be too sure.

Gather your most beloved family members, friends, frenemies and strangers for a game full of laughter, rivalry and revenge.

Do you have what it takes to become the Master of the Green Universe?

Sometimes, in order to truly appreciate a tale, one must first go back to its beginning. Grand adventures and strong fellowships are important and wonderful, but the first step of any journey is just as important as the last. With that in mind, it’s time to return to the beginning of one of the most epic adventures of all…

With increased contents and some quality-of-life improvements, this new version of the classic LCG’s core set is the perfect opportunity for a new player to dive into the game.

The Revised Core Set includes cards to allow Campaign Mode (previous core set was strictly standalone scenarios), entirely new Boon and Burden mechanics that add cards that persist with the players from scenario to scenario, and full support for 4 players in the core box.

-description from publisher

				
				
					What's new in this edition?
     Support for up to four players with a single core set (the original core set supported only two players, meaning players needed two core sets to play with three or four players)
     Three copies each of all 61 player cards from the original core set and eight copies of the Gandalf ally card (the original core set included only one or two copies of many of the player cards and only four copies of Gandalf)
     A narrative campaign that links the three scenarios included in the core set into an overarching story
     Quality-of-life improvements, such as new "3" and "5" numbered resource, progress and damage tokens
     Revised "Learn to Play" rulebook to allow new players to more easily jump right into playing, including two new decklists for players to try as a step up from the four starter decks


This set is 100% compatible with all previously-released The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game content. Players who already own three copies of the original core set will not find any new cards in this box, aside from the campaign, boon and burden cards, which can be downloaded and printed for free on the official website.

The two players play Surcouf, the Corsair, or Blackbeard, the Pirate. The two crews face each other with cannon shots symbolized by the rolls of the dice.

The object of the game is to decimate the crew of the opposing ship and then to sink it. Dice roll combinations will hit either the opposing crew or the opposing ship.

A new feature is the box serves as a dice track with bonus and penalty areas. Landing dice throws in these areas will take skill.



L'un des 4 jeux du coffret Jeux Pirates et Corsaires Légendaires. Au contraire des 3 autres jeux du coffret, celui-ci est une création originale.Les deux joueurs incarnent soit Surcouf, le Corsaire, soit Barbe Noire, le Pirate. Les deux équipages s'affrontent à coup de canon symbolisés par les jets de dés.

Le but du jeu est de décimer l'équipage du navire adverse puis de couler celui-ci.

L'originalité de ce jeu réside dans le fait que la boîte elle-même sert de piste de dés ayant des zones de bonus et de malus. Donc il est nécessaire de faire preuve d'adresse lors des lancers de dés.

Les combinaisons de chiffres des dés atteindront soit l'équipage, soit le navire adverses.

Kingscraft is a boardgame, that compresses the feeling of a classic RPG adventure into a board game of around an hour.

The story is, that the king is in search for a heir to his throne, that is equal to his own power. So he announces, that everyone in his kingdom may challenge him to a fair duel. And the first one to win, will be the new king. So adventurers from all over the country start building their equipment - in hope of becoming the new king.

Each turn the players choose one of seven actions-cards and place them face down on the table. Then the actions are revealed, placed in clear determined turn-order and then executed. Depending on the chosen actions, they take items from the board, fight monsters (dice-rolling) to get better loot and craft items together to get new advanced equipment.

In the centre of the game there is a transformable crafting-tree, where all players are trying to get the best equipment, by getting rewards for killing monsters and crafting different items together to get new and stronger ones.

The game is won by the first player who dares to fight the king and who succeeds in doing so.

Welcome to the world of fast LEGO building where you try to correctly guess who built what!

Players select a card from the stack and all players race to build the image out of Lego.  The player who builds best, wins the card.  The player with the most cards at the end of the games wins.

Contains:
100 Creation cards 
30 Two-point cards
20 One-point cards
1 Sixty-second sand timer

You will need to provide your own LEGO bricks.

This game was made available through the LEGO VIP program.

Meteors composed of strange, exotic matter have devastated the planet.  From the ashes, a few survivors have emerged with amazing, and sometimes terrifying, abilities! Some have come to defend the weak while others are set on conquering all they see.  The battle for the future of humanity has begun.

Heroes & Villains is a superhero/villain-themed deck battle game for 2 to 6 players.  Players use either preconstructed or their own customer battle deck of ability cards.  The battle deck is both your strength and your life.  Deplete all of the cards in your opponent's battle deck before exhausting your own and win the battle for ultimate supremacy!

To begin play, each player chooses one of the six powers types to play.  Each power has a corresponding Destiny Card that gives you the option to play as a Hero or Villain. Your choice empowers you with a unique bonus skill that can be used once per game) to give you a unique advantage in battle. Players can either use the pre-separated/pre-shuffled Power Deck for their character or assemble their own customize deck containing a unique blend of attacks and defense.

At the beginning of your turn, draw a card (max 5), and use your 4 Energy Points to Deploy Power Cards onto the BattleField, or to Active the Power of an already deployed card.  Use a balance of Tactics, Minions, Weapons, and Assaults to deplete your opponent’s deck and to restore your own.

Be the last man standing to be declared the winner, and the Ultimate Comic Book Hero/or Villain.

Bardo ("Flame War") is a real-life app where we will talk about EVERYTHING! The chat got heated. Display the menu of viral topics: everyone has their opinion and the fight is starting. We can make a big deal, make a mess or talk nonsense, know what we are talking about or not have a clue. All's fair in this game. Get ready for trolling in the group by playing your best cards.

Objective: Follow the conversation and discard the most Bardo cards throughout the game rounds. The winner is whoever runs out of cards first, or who has the least amount at the end of 3 rounds.

Deal 7 Bardo cards to each player. Put cellphone camera spots (Bardo cards background) on the table according to the number of players, to mark how many Bardo cards will be played each round. Choose a viral theme to talk about, from the menu or select one yourself.

A player starts playing one of their cards on a Bardo spot, and talking about the theme relating it to the Bardo card (by theme, feelings, or any way is valid). Words in the table cannot be mentioned, and a card would be taken as penalization if done. The player can be interrupted by other after 5 seconds or when they finish the idea. The interrupting player plays a new Bardo card, and has to answer or discuss the previous speech.

When all spots are covered, the round ends. The played cards are shuffled in the deck, and a vote is made (except on the last round) to penalize the most incongruent player on the round, with each player receiving an additional card for each vote they received against them.

The winner is whoever runs out of cards first, or who has the least amount at the end of 3 rounds.

Dragonville is a quick and simple strategy board game for ages 7+.

The Queen Dragon of Dragonville woke up one morning to find all her eggs missing. She soon discovered that her enemies had scattered her eggs around the forest. She has called upon the trusted champions of Dragonville to retrieve her eggs, and fast! “I will reward you all, my clan! Bring as many and as quickly as you can. Some combinations also fetch you more if you plan,”  she instructs.
â€‹
Are you going to be thorough, quick, or specific? What's your strategy?

Players race to collect eggs and be the first to complete the course.  On their turn, players decide to either move up to two spaces OR roll the dice for a chance to move up to five.  Landing on an egg spot first allows the player to pick up the egg.

The game ends when the first  player reaches the end of the forest. The player with the maximum points wins the game.

The players set their meeples in the center space and take turns rolling the die. Only at the roll of 1, the player has to move his meeple to the red dot of the inner circle. from this point on, he has to move clockwise after every roll. If he gets on a space connected to next ring, he has to change to that ring on his next turn. On the third ring there is a space which allows movement back to the first ring (connected with an arrow). On the fourth ring, there are spaces that cause the meeples to fall from the wheel and be taken out of the game.

The last player to remain on the board wins the game.

The boards where published without a box and without meeples and dice. Title and rules where glued to the back of the board.

Run Shark Run is a cooperative board game for kids aged between 5 and 13, where all players play together as a team against the Shark.

Players choose a card from the deck and play a card from their hand to move on the board.

Choose and play your cards wisely to go around the board and collect the treasure before the Shark gets to your boat to win the game.

"A Horribly Hilarious Horror Card Game!"

Every player is dealt 7 cards face down from the Method of Death deck. The oldest person in the room (i.e. the one closest to death) will assume the role of "Death Dealer."

At the top of each round, the Death Dealer will turn over one Killer and one Victim card from the top of the deck. The remaining players will all play one of their methods in an attempt to create the funniest or most gruesome (usually both) combination. This is decided on by the Death Dealer. Once the Death Dealer decides the winner of that round, the victim is given to the victor and it is added to that player's "body count." How many bodies is enough? Whatever it takes to make the players feel satisfied in their blood-lust.

Players will need to overcome several unique challenges in gameplay such as Plot Twists (cards that alter gameplay mechanics for Players and Death Dealers alike), Guardian Angels (cards that steal rounds from other Players), and Death Itself (cards that randomize gameplay in unexpected ways.)

Once the round is concluded, the person counter-clockwise to the first Death Dealer becomes the new Death Dealer and play resumes.

How high can you build it? Roll different dice combinations to build towers and earn bonus blocks. Create the tallest combined tower to win the game.

In Raise the Roofs, players take turns rolling the dice up to three times to create different combinations. These combinations are then used to build new towers, add blocks to existing towers, or reduce the height of an opponent's tower.  Once gameplay ends, each player combines their towers into a single tower, and the player with the tallest tower wins!

—description from the publisher

Save Afghanistan, Comrade! is a Solitaire board-wargame of the Soviet war in Afghanistan. Soviet and Afghan regiments and police battle Mujahadeen formations, foreign fighter contingents, and local chiefs and warlords for Provincial control throughout the country.

It is December, 1979. Hafizullah Amin, a dedicated communist, leads Afghanistan ineffectually. In Moscow, the Politburo chafes under his failure to unify an increasingly unraveling ally. The aging Leonid Brezhnev has been slowly persuaded that, absent decisive Russian action, Afghanistan will fall from the Soviet orbit.

In what they see as a quick “regime change”, the Politburo directs Soviet forces to deploy throughout Afghanistan under the guise of assisting Amin. On December 27, 1979, Amin’s palace is stormed and he is shot dead (then grenaded for good measure) and replaced by pliant Soviet puppet Babrak Karmal. Success! Or is it...?

Welcome to the Great Game, Cold War version. “Save Afghanistan, Comrade!” pits you as the Soviets and communist Afghans against the Mujahadeen for dominance there. You have until Summer, 1992 (50 quarterly turns) to clear the Provinces of Mujahadeen to win. Or will you, like Brezhnev, find the Mujahadeen to be an indomitable enemy?

In Splitter, you must group numbers together to score points — two 2s, three 3s, and so on — but you're placing two numbers at a time, so things won't always work out.

Each player has their own score sheet with 44 empty spaces on it, with two different patterns of spaces included in the box; each pattern has a dashed line through the middle that splits it into two mirrored halves.

On a turn, someone rolls two six-sided dice. Each player then writes the results, e.g. 1 and 4, in empty spaces in the pattern, with each number being in the mirrored space of the other. If, say, you place the 1 in the leftmost space of the top row, then you must place the 4 in the rightmost space of the top row.

After 22 dice rolls, everyone's pattern will be filled. Each 1 on its own — that is, with no other 1s orthogonally adjacent — scores 1 point; each set of two 2s that have no other orthogonally adjacent 2s score 2 points; and so on up to a set of six 6s with no other orthogonally adjacent 6s  being worth 6 points. A starred space is present on each half of the pattern, and a scored group that contains this starred space has its points doubled. (One pattern has a set of three spaces with hearts, and if you fill all three hearts with the same number, you score 5 points.)

Whoever has the highest score wins.

A solitaire game of the US and South Vietnamese war against the Vietcong and North Vietnamese Army. US and ARVN brigades/regiments and police battle VC battalions, NVA regiments, and subversive Political Cadres for Provincial control throughout the country.

It is early 1965. The South Vietnamese government and army (ARVN) are collapsing in the face of growing Vietcong attacks. President Johnson feels he MUST act. On March 8, 1965, the 9th Regiment, 3rd Marine Division, lands at Danang to take over the large base’s defense from ARVN forces who are presumably now free to conduct offensive operations against the VC. US Army units shortly deploy to Bien Hoa and other strategic areas. By fall 1965, the 1st Cavalry Division is engaged in a full-scale offensive in the Ia Drang Valley in Vietnam’s Central Highlands. "Americanization” of the war has begun. Before it's over 10 years later, Cambodia and Laos are dragged into the struggle. US forces leave Vietnam in 1973 having never lost a sizable battle, but South Vietnam quickly falls nonetheless, in early 1975.

Welcome back to 1965, now YOU are in command! The ARVN has basically collapsed and the North Vietnamese Army is infiltrating the south in large numbers even as local VC forces grow in strength. If you can hold Saigon until Summer 1977 (50 quarterly turns), the communists will be totally spent - Victory! Or will you, like Johnson and Nixon, find the VC and NVA impossible to completely defeat?

In this game players are managers of teams that are designing artificial intelligences. You are all working for the same research university, which will only give precious computer processing time to the teams whose AIs are doing the best. The game takes its inspiration from real-world “deep learning” techniques used when designing and building real AIs.

Unlike many games, Tensor is game of equilibrium, not efficiency, and you do not win by VPs. You will balance a board of 5 “weights” across many rounds through careful tile selection and placement, as well as special cards that let you change your tiles in unique ways.

On their turn the player takes one action, often placing a hexagonal tile on their board. The game ends when the draw pile of hexagonal tiles is exhausted.

At the end of the game, the player whose lowest weight is the highest wins! Be careful, as other players can hack your board!

Expands the original Truth or Drink: Extra Dirty deck into a Standalone version. 432 all-new questions guaranteed to shake things up. The set uses the rules from the from the Second Edition of the base game.

Definitely NSFW!

“Please help. I’ve kind of lost my memories and my… body!”

On your way to the 100 Year Winter Faire, you and your friends are interrupted by a mysterious little blue Wisp. 

“All this flying about isn’t so bad, but I don’t want to be stuck like this forever!” she says. “My only memory is of the Winter Faire, but that can’t be right… the last Faire was 100 years ago! 

Could you help solve this mystery and piece together who I am?

Frost is a printable escape room game that transforms any space into a DIY escape room adventure. This ready-to-play game pack is crafted to for 9-12-year-old kids, with puzzles that ignite their creativity, and a whimsical story they will cherish unraveling.

Players will work together to complete the trials of the Winter Faire, and uncover mysteriously forgotten memories before time runs out. Gameplay is centered on a series of puzzle sheets that you set up around the room. Each puzzle solved puts you one step closer to uncovering the Wisp’s long-lost past.

Game setup is quick and spoiler-free, and hints are handled by an online hint system that players access on their smartphones. This means that no game master is required to supervise the experience, so you can join the game alongside your players.

The game can expand to accommodate any number of players by dividing your group into teams of 2-4, and then pitting them against each other to see who finishes the game first. In addition, you can edit the game file before printing to customize your own escape room experience.

Cosmos: Infinity is an online and physical trading card game. You start with all the cards unlocked in the online game, and as you play, unlock card codes you can redeem for real physical copies of your cards.

The game itself if fairly unique, but a few of the mechanics utilised are as follows:

     Custom starting hand: You start the game with 5 cards of your own choosing in your hand.
     Board position matters: As you play cards, you grow your "tree" which allows you to play stronger cards. Your cards power up the card at the top of your "tree" allowing it to attack, and getting the cards lower in your tree to the top is not always easy.

A great roll-and-write adventure where you gather resources, build your crew and fight against your rivals to claim your place as the rightful Captain of the high seas.

On each player's turn. they roll dice, draft a single die unique to them, then all players pick 2 actions as detailed on the remaining dice.

The winner is the Captain with the most Reputation points at the end of the game.

One minute is not the world, right? Do you think so even if you have even less time to memorize every detail of an image? Memorace board game amusingly develops not only memory but also general knowledge and literacy. Learning becomes a captivating experience with its tasteful illustrations. How good is your memory?

You only have 10 seconds to observe every little detail and information on the card! With the help of the Amazing Inventions, a child can learn about the greatest achievements of mankind and their inventors. Who built the first airplane? When the ballpoint pen was invented? The answer lies in the cards. Will the player be able to memorize everything until the time runs out?

You can play Memorace alone or with more people.
1. Draw a card and place it in front of you.
2. Turn the clock over and try to memorize as many details as possible before the sand drips off - it’s about 10 seconds.
3. Roll the dice!
4. If you rolled 1, you must answer the thought-provoking puzzle on the front. Look at the picture and calculate or deduce correctly!
5. If you did not roll a 1, turn the card over and answer the question on the back next to the rolled number. These will put your memory to the test, but if you watch well, you will know the answer for sure!

If you answered correctly, you keep the card and earn a point.
The player with the most points, wins.

Who will collect the most cards? Can you break your own record?

The place and time of the game - the used car market in the 90s. Players play for car dealers. Each car dealer has its own unique feature that helps to achieve the goal. The goal is to earn $5000 by selling used cars. Players can make money profitably by selling cars or working with loaders at a vegetable market. Players can interfere with each other by using dedicated “PrijomÅ³” cards.

The game is full of various jargon: from car dealers and mechanic terms to street slang. In order not to get lost, a glossary with slang explanations and other fun has been added to the game.


Å½aidimo vieta ir laikas – dÄ—vÄ—tÅ³ automobiliÅ³ turgus 90-aisiais. Å½aidÄ—jai Å¾aidÅ¾ia uÅ¾ perekupus. Kiekvienas Perekupas turi savo išskirtinÄ™ savybÄ™, kuri padeda siekiant tikslo. Tikslas – uÅ¾dirbti $5000 pardavinÄ—jant dÄ—vÄ—tas mašinas. Pinigus Å¾aidÄ—jai gali uÅ¾dirbti pelningai pardavinÄ—dami Mašinas arba dirbdami krovikais darÅ¾oviÅ³ turguje. Å½aidÄ—jai gali trukdyti vieni kitiems naudodami tam skirtas “PrijomÅ³” kortas.

Å½aidime gausu Ä¯vairaus Å¾argono: nuo perekupÅ³ ir mechanikÅ³ terminÅ³ iki gatvinio slengo. Kad nepasimesti tarp babinÅ³, prakladkiÅ³, moldingÅ³ ir kitÅ³ gerÅ³ dalykÅ³, prie Å¾aidimo pridÄ—tas Å¾odynÄ—lis su slengo paaiškinimais ir kitais smagumynais.

Each turn in Vikings Gone Wild — a deck-building, resource management game based on the online real-time strategy game — players can either buy permanent buildings sitting in front of them (resource factories, resources containers, etc) or buy units, towers and special cards that improve their deck and offense/defense capacity.

The only way to win is by successfully attacking each other, and each attack involves interesting bluffing mechanisms in which the attacker doesn't know the defense capacity of their opponent...

NOTE: This contains the 5th player expansion

Noir is a card game where players take the role of a mafia bosses during the Prohibition Era.

Noirbrough has only a limited amount of money that can be earned by crime and it is not enough for more than two ambitious mafia boses.

Game can be played by 3 to 6 players but 4 to 5 players is preferable for the best experience.

Each round is divided into three phases:
1. Preparation: Collect income from your businesses, relocate your hideout and gangsters, discard and draw cards.
2. Attack: Attack using your gangsters.
3. Deploy: Deploy new businesses and gangsters.

The player who destroys all her enemies or earns more than half the money in the city wins.

Mystery Kingdom is a deduction game based on perceptiveness and fact matching. Players take the role of mages working on the chronicles of the fantasy land. Looking through the jumble of events they try to put them in order and solve puzzles about which events influenced the future of the kingdom. 
During the game players have 9 maps at their disposal which represent a fragment of the fantasy land. These maps are filled with various scenes in which inhabitants and magical creatures take part.
Players learn a mission which consists in finding a particular event on the map on the basis of its description, the coordinates of this place are a password to open a PDF with the next task (for this purpose we use a computer or a phone - to read tasks from PDF files). In this way the players go through the story scenarios during which they also draw on the map and color its elements. The game is cooperative and players win when they manage to solve all puzzles and learn all passwords in a given scenario. All scenarios make up one big campaign

—description from the designer

"Creative Kids" is a collection of simple educational games in a 'Print and Play' format for use at school/daycare/home. The set consists of:
-Tetrigo- stacking blocks based on the rules of the game tetris.Each player places blocks (which are determined by a dice roll) on their board in such a way as to cover the scoring fields. The player with the highest sum of points wins

-Seal- guide a seal through a section of the ocean.The player chooses what kind of movement the seal has to make on the board (which are disposable), along the way it has to avoid dangers and collect points in the form of fish. The player who earns the most points wins

-Hello Autumn- collecting leaves in autumn
Players assign dice values to a puzzle that must meet certain values. They receive points for meeting the condition (e.g., an even sum of dice, greater than a given number, etc.). The player with the highest point total wins

-Bee home- a puzzle about creating a bee route to the hive.
The player arranges a travel route for 3 bees of different colors from random pieces. The player who arranges the route first wins

-Block Craft - extracting resources from a mine.Players draw a pit shape which they then draw on their choice of 6 pit maps. This way they extract treasures while avoiding weak points that can collapse the mine. The player who has the highest treasure score at the end of the game wins

-Just Run- a dog race on an obstacle course
Players roll two D6 dice. They choose one of the results and move their character by that many spaces on the map. In this way they earn points and collect sets. Getting to the finish line first also gives a big point bonus. The player with the highest amount of points at the end of the game wins the game

-Impostor- find hidden on the map space traitors.One player secretly marks the position of the 3 astronauts. The other players use 10 questions to try to guess the position of each astronaut. Players who guess correctly are awarded points. Then they switch roles. The player who gets the most points wins the game

-Bowling snap- Players draw the path of the bowling ball. Then they cut it out and put it on the board scoring bonus points and penalties. After 5 courses, the player with the highest sum of points wins

-Pixel People- Players draw a task then arrange the human elements (heads, torso, legs, shoes) into a whole human. Each element has a point value, the goal is to create a man who will have the same value as the task. We arrange 3 people as quickly as possible, the player who does it first wins the game

-My farm- Each turn, players roll a pool of 6 D6 dice. These resources serve as currency with which they buy and improve animals living on the farm, build fences. Some animals can only live in an enclosure with certain others. Each animal gives a certain number of points. The player who has the highest point total at the end wins

-Seeker - Each player gets a board with 100 drawings labeled with numbers. One player chooses a picture and describes it, the rest of the players have to give the number of the picture as quickly as possible, the first one who does that gets a point. After 10 turns we count the points and the player who scored the highest amount wins

The games form a coherent set, outside of which they are not accessible in any way. Each of them contains some educational element and they are designed for children 5+

A team is investigating four cases in the dreamy coastal town of Redcliff Bay. It's not that easy at all. When looking for traces, the 1-5 players encounter very idiosyncratic inhabitants with special peculiarities. Suspicious, right?

Round by round, the team decides where to continue investigating this crime thriller at the current time. Together, the team weighs up where the most useful information is currently available or where the most interesting things are going on. An exciting story, simple rules and weird characters - the ideal detective game for families.


Seltsames geht hier vor! Ein Team nimmt im verträumten Küstenort Redcliff Bay die Ermittlungen in vier Fällen auf. Das ist gar nicht so einfach: Bei der Suche nach Spuren treffen die 1-5 Spieler und Spielerinnen nämlich auf sehr eigenwillige Einwohner mit speziellen Eigenheiten. Verdächtig, oder? Runde für Runde entscheidet das Team, an welchem Ort es zur aktuellen Uhrzeit in diesem Krimi weiterermittelt. Gemeinsam wägt das Team ab, wo es gerade wohl die nützlichsten Informationen gibt oder die interessantesten Dinge vor sich gehen. Eine spannende Geschichte, einfache Regeln und schräge Charaktere – das ideale Detektiv-Spiel für Familien.

Sammu-ramat ruled the Assyrian Empire at a time of political uncertainty, which is one of the possible explanations for why Assyrians may have accepted her rule (as normally a woman as ruler would have been unthinkable). Her reign lasted between 811 BC – 808 BC. In this collaborative game you the players are Sammu-ramat, together with advisors surrounding the royal court and vassal states, you try to keep the Empire strong and protected against internal unrest, external threats, natural disasters and much more. All players win or lose together.

In this 1-5 player co-op board game, you will be one of the advisors surrounding the Assyrian royal court. Each Advisor has its own abilities and strengths. Players spend actions to play action cards and move from region to region along the paths printed on the board, trying to balance the needs of the regions (Military, Supplies, Health, and Diviners). In battle with the enemy units are removed 1:1, i.e. combat is deterministic.

Your mission in each game you play is to assist Sammu-ramat through one of the many challenges that she encountered during her reign. This challenge is presented to you as a scenario, found on a Challenge card that you draw during setup. Apart from completing the scenario, players need to make sure that the Empire is stable and that Queen Sammu-ramat is safe.

This is a tennis simulation. The game is played between two players. They draw cards and the one with the highest number wins first serve and the player figure is put on space 45 or 44. Serve and return of service are resolved by drawing cards and following the drawn numbers. Then the players must draw a retrieve to reach the ball (move the playing figure) and to shoot the ball into the opponents court.

Scoring is the same as in actual tennis. The player winning six games first with a two-game margin, wins the set.

It is also possible to play Doubles.

Starting player presses the button on top of the beaver's head and sounds of the forest start playing. Then players take turns rolling the die and based on the result you either move one of your squirrels forward from one treetop to another or move another player's squirrel backward. This continues until the the music stops and the beaver slams the pond with its tail and some of the trees fall. Squirrels from the fallen treetops are moved back to start and the trees are turned back up. Whoever is able to get both of their squirrels first all the way around the pond wins.

Do your friends know what your dream holiday destination is or which celebrity would you choose to dine with?

Test them by offering them a question and a set of alternatives and let them answer with answering cards. All players in majority group win a card and first to 5 cards wins!

Competitors, welcome to Jungle Dash! You have been selected from among thousands of applicants to compete in this gruelling race through the Amazon Rainforest; however, only one can be crowned champion.

Jungle Dash is a race through the Amazon Rainforest for 2-6 players with push-your-luck and take-that mechanics.

On your turn, play Cards to overcome obstacles or hinder your opponents and roll the dice to move your Token. You may reroll failed dice to gain a bigger advantage, but you risk losing them all. The jungle terrain is slowly revealed as players progress, requiring that strategies adjust on the fly to overcome the new challenges.

The first player out of the jungle wins.

Duty calls is a 28mm miniatures game designed to recreate modern and contemporary conflict in solo game or in cooperation mode. The game involves the use of infantry troops but it is also possible to implement air vehicles and supports for more substantial games. The aim of the game will be to free the streets and war zones from hostile objectives that will reveal themselves during the game in an unexpected way...

Game and war theaters 
The game involves armed clashes and it is advisable to use a game table full of scenic elements to make the combat more exciting.  The size of the table is at the discretion of the player and the mission you want to play but for a standard game it is advisable to start on a 3 '× 3' table.

Necessary material:
2d6, 1d20 one meter per inch, paper and pencil

–description from the publisher

Crossroads Inn. The Innkeepers' Creed is a fantasy engine-building strategy board game where you embody one of 4 competitive innkeepers, struggling to grow their taverns and attract customers from all over the world.

In the meantime, the medieval kingdom of Yorevale has monarchs die in mysterious circumstances and their illegitimate heirs competing with each other for influence and power.

YOU pursue fame, fortune and renown with your own inn - and perhaps, will have your eyes on the royal crown, too!

BUILD YOUR INN FROM SCRATCH!

Have you ever wondered what goes behind the scenes at a medieval inn in a fantasy world setting? Look no further!

Furnish, hire staff, and cook exquisite meals to satisfy guests from various social groups. Anticipate and block the actions of your rival Players, fellow innkeepers - in the end, there can only be one winner to rule them all!

HOW TO PLAY
â­ Build Your Inn
â­ Gain Reputation
â­ Compete against other Innkeepers

There is plenty of room for good innkeepers in the Kingdom, but only one can rule them all! Compete for fame, fortune, and renown with your own inn - and perhaps, you will have your eyes on the royal crown, too!

In 2107, two planets are on the verge of an interstellar war. As the vanguard commander of AstroSnipe, your mission is to navigate through black holes and chaotic asteroids between the planets and snipe at the enemy's planet to make the first strike!

Qloxx: AstroSnipe is a 2-player abstract strategy game about connections and obstructions in the size of a matchbox! By laying down and replacing the 9 Pathway tiles on the board, you control your troops' laser to shoot down enemy fleets and establish safe encampments for back-ups. The side that first strikes the enemy Home Planet will claim victory!

Players place place or remove tiles on the centre board, or exchange one for another from hand.

The game ends and you win when the enemy Planet Tile (like the King in chess) is removed from the board. The game may also ends in a draw if both players are exchanging the same 3 tiles on the same spot for over a full cycle.

In Sacrifice, 5 players take turns placing cubes in a grid, hoping to score many points.  Players may only place a cube in the left-most empty space of a row.  Some spaces require a player to remove other cubes they have placed.

Once every space on the board is full, the game ends and players are awarded points based upon the spaces they occupy, with a bonus in each row for whomever has the most and second-most cubes.

The player with the most points wins.

The game also includes a variant for 4 people to play with a non-player character taking the fifth color.

In æˆ¦å›½ãƒ–ãƒªãƒƒã‚¸ (Sengoku Bridge), a trick-taking game, the players discard cards from an initial hand in order to draft special powers or conditions that will define the hand.  (Cards discarded are shuffled and redistributed so that players have the same number of cards in hand.)

Some powers allow a player to choose the trump suit, for instance.  Another power gives a player the Joker, the highest card in the game, which they can play regardless of if they could have followed suit.  Yet another power allows that player to never need to follow suit. There is another power that if a player can reveal a hand of cards that all share a suit, that suit immediately becomes trump.

Tricks are not worth any points, but collecting certain ranks is.  The player with the most points at the end of a hand is the winner.

A French-language crossword card game published in Quebec.

Each player starts with 10 cards (or 7 if six people play), each with a letter on it. On your turn you play cards forming a word onto the table; after the first turn the word must fit with the others in a crossword fashion similar to Scrabble. Instead of playing a word, you may discard a card and draw from the deck or discard pile.

When someone plays all the cards from their hand, the other players add up the points remaining in their hand (5 points per consonant, 10 per vowel, 15 for the wild Richelieu card), and add it to their total.  When someone reaches an agreed-on total (e.g. 100 points), the player with the fewest points wins.

Your long and perilous journey home is almost over. Only one last obstacle stands between you and your destination: that wobbly suspension bridge, unstable and treacherous, especially when winter is approaching and the wind is blowing in icy, unpredictable gusts. One false step, one shift, and you could lose part of your precious cargo. Hunger and cold will also sap your strength.  And the night which is inevitably approaching will be your doom if it catches up with you before you have found refuge on dry land, on the other side of the bridge. Despite all these dangers, you set off and begin the crossing.

Each turn, players will program a few actions from their board (with action tokens) and resolve them. This will often involve moving forward along the bridge, revealing and resolving bridge cards and potentially weather cards. The game ends when the bridge is crossed or the night has caught up to the character or too much cargo has been lost along the way.

Step into the Grand Bazaar of Tabriz and become a legendary master weaver! From Randy Flynn, the designer of Cascadia, Tabriz blends elegant engine-building with accessible strategy and a rich, cultural setting that comes alive on your table.

Gather rare materials like silk, camel hair, and plant dye as you weave exquisite Persian rugs to fulfill commissions and earn prestige. Use your three assistants to navigate a bustling bazaar, time your moves with shifting market prices, and build a powerful action engine that grows with every rug you complete.

Tabriz offers intuitive mechanics, satisfying progression, and multiple solo AIs for deep replayability. Tabriz is your next relaxing-yet-clever strategy favorite!

You are a skilled carpet weaver in the bustling Persian market city of Tabriz, and your goal is to become the best known master of your craft. You accomplish this through savvy acquisitions from the market row and tactical completion of commoner, merchant, and royal commissions.

The heart of Tabriz: The Card Game is the commission grid, an irregularly shaped series of resource requirement cards that form commissions in columns and rows. Complete a commission by dedicating the necessary resources for an entire column or row, removing those requirements from the grid and changing all other commissions at the same time. Commissions are defined by their length:


     3 cards is a common commission 
     4 cards is a merchant commission
     5 cards is a royal commission


Complete commissions with more cards for better rewards, including more coins and higher prestige. Merchant and royal commissions also earn you permanent abilities that contribute to your game engine.

On your turn, take two actions. Actions include buying a material card from the market row, trading a material card you have for one in the market row, purging the market row, or taking five coins from the supply. At the end of each turn, if you have the necessary materials, you may complete one commission on the grid, and by claiming this commission card, you change the grid for future turns.

Earn the most prestige by the time the commission deck runs out, and you become the master weaver of Tabriz!

In Catastrophe, you and your friends prepare for an unforeseen disaster, securing resources and surviving the impacts to emerge alive together!

Players may be hit with any one of Catastrophe’s nine possible disasters. Can you survive an earthquake? What about a volcano or cyber attack? Maybe a radiological disaster will test your mettle. Strategize your way through seven potential emergency impacts with a wild card each round that will catch everyone by surprise. Will you hoard your resources or share with your neighbors?

The player who survives with the most vitality tokens will win, but be careful — if anyone perishes, the game is lost for all!

A board game that looks at emotions, life skills and moral dilemmas in a fun way.

Each player chooses a character and then they each take turns going around the board and answering either questions on certain cards or collecting baggage and skills cards each relating to emotions, life skills, social rules and moral dilemmas. A player can win the game if they have the most skills cards and the least baggage cards in a certain timespan.

Snack Time is a Roll and Write game for an unlimited number of players. Each round a player will roll 5 dice which will include appendages to add to your creatures as well as sewer pipes to guide them to the surface.

Players are scored based on their ability to take a small bite out of people passing by and the quality of the people you snack on. If you aren't careful then the pedestrians will fight back and your creatures will be injured in their quest for food.

At the beginning of the round the pedestrians will move down the street visiting different locations. Someone will roll the dice and all players will add traits to their creatures and add pipes to their sewer. Then everyone will check to see if one of their creatures can take a bite out of a pedestrian! This depends on being in the right location and having the right traits to overwhelm your prey!

The Game ends when one player has completely fed all of their monsters or when a player gets caught by the authorities! Scores are based on the quality of food... I mean, people you ate, as well as how much damage your creatures sustained.

Keep your monsters healthy and happy and don't alert the authorities or you will incur heavy penalties because snitches get stitches.

The object of the game is to match quotations to the person from the Bible, on character cards, the first player to match all of their character cards is the winner.

Each player starts with seven character cards, on their turn, they draw a quote card and (if they can) they play the appropriate character card from their hand, if they are wrong they draw a new character card.

The game ends when one player has played all of their character cards, and that player is the winner.

Gather your courage, pack your sword, and roll the dice as you journey through the realm in search of treasure and glory. In the roll-and-write game Dungeons, Dice, & Danger, you explore deep, dark dungeons filled with treasure — and infested with monsters! Do you have what it takes to be a hero of legend?

—description from the publisher

Double sided wooden board offers two different games, both based on slinging your pieces with elastic band.

In Shuffle Game players try to move their pieces around a path and land their pieces in a scoring area to get most points. Scoring area is divided in five parts, each giving different amount of points. If a piece lands in "Out" area it scores 0 points. Not being able to land in scoring area results in negative points.

In Speed Hockey players shoot their pieces through small slot in the middle of the playing field. The first player to bring all pieces onto opponent´s side wins the game.

In many societies of the world there is corruption with its different popular sayings "bite, bribery, CHORIZO, etc."
The Chorizo â€‹â€‹game is designed to show some forms of corruption that exist in the world.

The purpose of the game is to understand what corruption is, how to avoid it and teach players to avoid this evil. Say no to corruption, say yes to Chorizo â€‹â€‹game!

The game its similar to monopoly or petrodollars, with few differences where you have to go through elections to became president You roll a dice, move around the board and instead of buying properties, you buy corrupt politicians (judges, deputies, transit police, etc) The idea is that you try to be president as many times as possible to accumulate money buying, selling or exchanging properties

The game ends when with one of the following situations:
1) when all the players became elected president at least one time, then finish the last round until next elections
2) setting up a time limit at the beginning of the game

The player who collects the most money wins

The goal is for each player to be president as many times as possible and accumulate the most money.


En muchas sociedades del mundo existe la corrupción con sus diferentes dichos populares "mordida, soborno, CHORIZO, etc."
El juego chorizo esta diseñado para mostrar unas formas de corrupción que hay en el mundo.
la finalidad del juego es el entender que es la corrupción, como evitarla y enseñar a los jugadores a evitar este mal. !Di no a la corrupción, di si al juego chorizo!
